head.title: Review/Pop; Youth and Tradition Mix In Cheb Khaled's Sound

hedline.hl1: Review/Pop; Youth and Tradition Mix In Cheb Khaled's Sound

block.p: Cheb Khaled's late set on Wednesday night at S.O.B.'s sketched the path of rai, a kind of Algerian pop, as it was transformed by contact with Europe. Rai is the music of Oran's younger generations -- cheb means young -- and incorporates electric instruments, but Cheb Khaled showed he is grounded in older styles.

He is one of rai's biggest stars; the audience cheered the beginning of every song and danced throughout the set. Although rai doesn't call for a wide vocal range -- Mr. Khaled sang almost his entire set within less than an octave -- it calls for ardent tone and precise intonation, so that even the slightest microtonal turns and shakes ring with passion.

Rai is the music of Oran's younger generations -- cheb means young -- and incorporates electric instruments, but Cheb Khaled showed he is grounded in older styles.

He is one of rai's biggest stars; the audience cheered the beginning of every song and danced throughout the set. Although rai doesn't call for a wide vocal range -- Mr. Khaled sang almost his entire set within less than an octave -- it calls for ardent tone and precise intonation, so that even the slightest microtonal turns and shakes ring with passion.

Mr. Khaled's first songs evoked Arabic music; over a sustained chord and the beat of a hand drum, he would sing long, incantatory phrases, answering his own voice with scampering accordion lines. As the set progressed, he put away the accordion and a drummer joined the band. The songs turned into North African funk, with modal bass lines, a keyboard that sounded alternately like an Arabic reed flute or synthesized bells, and an unhurried but danceable syncopation.

Gradually, more Western touches appeared. The band's trumpeter switched from improvisatory lines to repeating riffs; harmonies changed from drones to chord sequences; the keyboardist started to play repeated hooks; melody phrases, though still full of Arabic flavor, changed to four-bar lengths that sound more familiar to the Western ear. By late in the set, Cheb Khaled was scat-singing along with a bass line. But through it all, the band maintained a propulsive syncopation, without the corny drum-machine rhythms of many rai records. And Mr. Khaled, smiling and dancing, let his voice tease out all the fervor his songs could hold.
Cheb Khaled is to perform tomorrow in a concert beginning at 3 P.M. at Summerstage at Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street in Central Park.
